hypothesis_content.title: Volatility Surge Cooldown Timing
hypothesis_content.statement: Following a STRESS regime spike (1-hour realized volatility > 95th percentile), the transition back to a NEUTRAL regime (as per regime classifier) often occurs via a specific pattern: a final sharp, high-volume directional candle that exhausts the move, providing a timing edge to fade the exhaustion candle's extreme.
hypothesis_content.rationale: STRESS regimes end with a volatility climax. A high-volume, wide-range candle with a weak close (long wick) suggests a final flush or squeeze that exhausts the dominant momentum. The immediate rejection back into the candle's body signals a potential regime shift, offering a timed entry at the point of momentum reversal.
entry_conditions: Market has been in STRESS regime for at least 4 hours.
A 1-hour candle closes with volume > 150% of its 20-hour average and a range > 2.5%.
This 'exhaustion candle' closes in the top/bottom 20% of its range (i.e., a long wick).
The subsequent 1-hour candle opens and trades back into the body of the exhaustion candle.
Regime classifier shows a drop in STRESS probability and rise in NEUTRAL probability on the 4-hour scale.

exit_conditions.take_profit: 50% retracement of the exhaustion candle's full range.
exit_conditions.stop_loss: A close beyond the extreme (high/low) of the exhaustion candle.

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: After the described sequence, price continues beyond the exhaustion candle extreme more than 35% of the time before achieving a 50% retracement, indicating the move was not exhaustive.
